conclusion: Identify the contact forces for Sphere A and Sphere B.
Sphere A has a weight mg down, wall reaction N₁ to the right, wall friction f vertical, and reaction from B N₂ along line AB.
Line AB makes 30° with the horizontal, force on A from B directed 30° below the –x axis.
Sphere B has a weight 2mg down, wall reaction N₃ to the left, and reaction from A N₂ along AB.
All contacts except A–wall are smooth, only A-wall can exert friction.
Just-about-to-slide means static friction equals kinetic value, f = μN₁.
Equilibrium of sphere B with +x to the right, +y upward.
Horizontal equilibrium of sphere B: N₂ cos 30° – N₃ = 0, hence N₃ = N₂ cos 30°.
Vertical equilibrium of sphere B: N₂ sin 30° – 2mg = 0, hence N₂ sin 30° = 2mg.
Horizontal forces on sphere A: N₁ – N₂ cos 30° = 0, hence N₁ = N₂ cos 30°.
Vertical forces on sphere A: f – N₂ sin 30° – mg = 0.
Substitute into horizontal balance: N₁ = (4mg) cos 30° = 2√3 mg.
Substitute into vertical balance: f = μN₁ = μ(2√3 mg).
Insert N₂ into vertical balance: μ(2√3 mg) – 2mg – mg = 0, hence μ(2√3 mg) = 3mg.
Solve for μ: μ(2√3) = 3, hence μ = √3 / 2 ≈ 0.866.
Final answer: The kinetic coefficient of friction between hemisphere A and the left wall is μ = √3 ⁄ 2 ≈ 0.87.
